speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, HERO, and BEATRICE, with a Messenger
speech.text: I learn in this letter that Don Peter of Arragon comes this night to Messina.

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, HERO, and BEATRICE, with a Messenger
speech.text: He is very near by this: he was not three leagues off when I left him.

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, HERO, and BEATRICE, with a Messenger
speech.text: How many gentlemen have you lost in this action?

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, HERO, and BEATRICE, with a Messenger
speech.text: But few of any sort, and none of name.

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, HERO, and BEATRICE, with a Messenger
speech.text: A victory is twice itself when the achiever brings home full numbers. I find here that Don Peter hath bestowed much honour on a young Florentine called Claudio.

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, HERO, and BEATRICE, with a Messenger
speech.text: Much deserved on his part and equally remembered by Don Pedro: he hath borne himself beyond the promise of his age, doing, in the figure of a lamb, the feats of a lion: he hath indeed better bettered expectation than you must expect of me to tell you how.

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, HERO, and BEATRICE, with a Messenger
speech.text: He hath an uncle here in Messina will be very much glad of it.

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, HERO, and BEATRICE, with a Messenger
speech.text: I have already delivered him letters, and there appears much joy in him; even so much that joy could not show itself modest enough without a badge of bitterness.

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, HERO, and BEATRICE, with a Messenger
speech.text: Did he break out into tears?

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, HERO, and BEATRICE, with a Messenger
speech.text: In great measure.

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, HERO, and BEATRICE, with a Messenger
speech.text: A kind overflow of kindness: there are no faces truer than those that are so washed. How much better is it to weep at joy than to joy at weeping!

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, HERO, and BEATRICE, with a Messenger
speech.text: I pray you, is Signior Mountanto returned from the wars or no?

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, HERO, and BEATRICE, with a Messenger
speech.text: I know none of that name, lady: there was none such in the army of any sort.

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, HERO, and BEATRICE, with a Messenger
speech.text: What is he that you ask for, niece?

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, HERO, and BEATRICE, with a Messenger
speech.text: My cousin means Signior Benedick of Padua.

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, HERO, and BEATRICE, with a Messenger
speech.text: O, he's returned; and as pleasant as ever he was.

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, HERO, and BEATRICE, with a Messenger
speech.text: He set up his bills here in Messina and challenged Cupid at the flight; and my uncle's fool, reading the challenge, subscribed for Cupid, and challenged him at the bird-bolt. I pray you, how many hath he killed and eaten in these wars? But how many hath he killed? for indeed I promised to eat all of his killing.

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, HERO, and BEATRICE, with a Messenger
speech.text: Faith, niece, you tax Signior Benedick too much; but he'll be meet with you, I doubt it not.

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, HERO, and BEATRICE, with a Messenger
speech.text: He hath done good service, lady, in these wars.

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, HERO, and BEATRICE, with a Messenger
speech.text: You had musty victual, and he hath holp to eat it: he is a very valiant trencherman; he hath an excellent stomach.

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, HERO, and BEATRICE, with a Messenger
speech.text: And a good soldier too, lady.

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, HERO, and BEATRICE, with a Messenger
speech.text: And a good soldier to a lady: but what is he to a lord?

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, HERO, and BEATRICE, with a Messenger
speech.text: A lord to a lord, a man to a man; stuffed with all honourable virtues.

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, HERO, and BEATRICE, with a Messenger
speech.text: It is so, indeed; he is no less than a stuffed man: but for the stuffing,--well, we are all mortal.

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, HERO, and BEATRICE, with a Messenger
speech.text: You must not, sir, mistake my niece. There is a kind of merry war betwixt Signior Benedick and her: they never meet but there's a skirmish of wit between them.

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, HERO, and BEATRICE, with a Messenger
speech.text: Alas! he gets nothing by that. In our last conflict four of his five wits went halting off, and now is the whole man governed with one: so that if he have wit enough to keep himself warm, let him bear it for a difference between himself and his horse; for it is all the wealth that he hath left, to be known a reasonable creature. Who is his companion now? He hath every month a new sworn brother.

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, HERO, and BEATRICE, with a Messenger
speech.text: Is't possible?

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, HERO, and BEATRICE, with a Messenger
speech.text: Very easily possible: he wears his faith but as the fashion of his hat; it ever changes with the next block.

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, HERO, and BEATRICE, with a Messenger
speech.text: I see, lady, the gentleman is not in your books.

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, HERO, and BEATRICE, with a Messenger
speech.text: No; an he were, I would burn my study. But, I pray you, who is his companion? Is there no young squarer now that will make a voyage with him to the devil?

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, HERO, and BEATRICE, with a Messenger
speech.text: He is most in the company of the right noble Claudio.

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, HERO, and BEATRICE, with a Messenger
speech.text: O Lord, he will hang upon him like a disease: he is sooner caught than the pestilence, and the taker runs presently mad. God help the noble Claudio! if he have caught the Benedick, it will cost him a thousand pound ere a' be cured.

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, HERO, and BEATRICE, with a Messenger
speech.text: I will hold friends with you, lady.

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, HERO, and BEATRICE, with a Messenger
speech.text: Do, good friend.

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, HERO, and BEATRICE, with a Messenger
speech.text: You will never run mad, niece.

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, HERO, and BEATRICE, with a Messenger
speech.text: No, not till a hot January.

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, HERO, and BEATRICE, with a Messenger
speech.text: Don Pedro is approached.

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, DON JOHN, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and BALTHASAR
speech.text: Good Signior Leonato, you are come to meet your trouble: the fashion of the world is to avoid cost, and you encounter it.

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, DON JOHN, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and BALTHASAR
speech.text: Never came trouble to my house in the likeness of your grace: for trouble being gone, comfort should remain; but when you depart from me, sorrow abides and happiness takes his leave.

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, DON JOHN, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and BALTHASAR
speech.text: You embrace your charge too willingly. I think this is your daughter.

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, DON JOHN, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and BALTHASAR
speech.text: Her mother hath many times told me so.

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, DON JOHN, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and BALTHASAR
speech.text: Were you in doubt, sir, that you asked her?

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, DON JOHN, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and BALTHASAR
speech.text: Signior Benedick, no; for then were you a child.

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, DON JOHN, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and BALTHASAR
speech.text: You have it full, Benedick: we may guess by this what you are, being a man. Truly, the lady fathers herself. Be happy, lady; for you are like an honourable father.

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, DON JOHN, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and BALTHASAR
speech.text: If Signior Leonato be her father, she would not have his head on her shoulders for all Messina, as like him as she is.

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, DON JOHN, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and BALTHASAR
speech.text: I wonder that you will still be talking, Signior Benedick: nobody marks you.

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, DON JOHN, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and BALTHASAR
speech.text: What, my dear Lady Disdain! are you yet living?

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, DON JOHN, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and BALTHASAR
speech.text: Is it possible disdain should die while she hath such meet food to feed it as Signior Benedick? Courtesy itself must convert to disdain, if you come in her presence.

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, DON JOHN, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and BALTHASAR
speech.text: Then is courtesy a turncoat. But it is certain I am loved of all ladies, only you excepted: and I would I could find in my heart that I had not a hard heart; for, truly, I love none.

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, DON JOHN, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and BALTHASAR
speech.text: A dear happiness to women: they would else have been troubled with a pernicious suitor. I thank God and my cold blood, I am of your humour for that: I had rather hear my dog bark at a crow than a man swear he loves me.

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, DON JOHN, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and BALTHASAR
speech.text: God keep your ladyship still in that mind! so some gentleman or other shall 'scape a predestinate scratched face.

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, DON JOHN, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and BALTHASAR
speech.text: Scratching could not make it worse, an 'twere such a face as yours were.

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, DON JOHN, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and BALTHASAR
speech.text: Well, you are a rare parrot-teacher.

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, DON JOHN, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and BALTHASAR
speech.text: A bird of my tongue is better than a beast of yours.

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, DON JOHN, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and BALTHASAR
speech.text: I would my horse had the speed of your tongue, and so good a continuer. But keep your way, i' God's name; I have done.

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, DON JOHN, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and BALTHASAR
speech.text: You always end with a jade's trick: I know you of old.

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, DON JOHN, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and BALTHASAR
speech.text: That is the sum of all, Leonato. Signior Claudio and Signior Benedick, my dear friend Leonato hath invited you all. I tell him we shall stay here at the least a month; and he heartily prays some occasion may detain us longer. I dare swear he is no hypocrite, but prays from his heart.

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, DON JOHN, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and BALTHASAR
speech.text: If you swear, my lord, you shall not be forsworn. Let me bid you welcome, my lord: being reconciled to the prince your brother, I owe you all duty.

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, DON JOHN, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and BALTHASAR
speech.text: I thank you: I am not of many words, but I thank you.

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, DON JOHN, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and BALTHASAR
speech.text: Please it your grace lead on?

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, DON JOHN, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and BALTHASAR
speech.text: Your hand, Leonato; we will go together.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all except BENEDICK and CLAUDIO
speech.text: Benedick, didst thou note the daughter of Signior Leonato?

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all except BENEDICK and CLAUDIO
speech.text: I noted her not; but I looked on her.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all except BENEDICK and CLAUDIO
speech.text: Is she not a modest young lady?

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all except BENEDICK and CLAUDIO
speech.text: Do you question me, as an honest man should do, for my simple true judgment; or would you have me speak after my custom, as being a professed tyrant to their sex?

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all except BENEDICK and CLAUDIO
speech.text: No; I pray thee speak in sober judgment.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all except BENEDICK and CLAUDIO
speech.text: Why, i' faith, methinks she's too low for a high praise, too brown for a fair praise and too little for a great praise: only this commendation I can afford her, that were she other than she is, she were unhandsome; and being no other but as she is, I do not like her.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all except BENEDICK and CLAUDIO
speech.text: Thou thinkest I am in sport: I pray thee tell me truly how thou likest her.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all except BENEDICK and CLAUDIO
speech.text: Would you buy her, that you inquire after her?

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all except BENEDICK and CLAUDIO
speech.text: Can the world buy such a jewel?

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all except BENEDICK and CLAUDIO
speech.text: Yea, and a case to put it into. But speak you this with a sad brow? or do you play the flouting Jack, to tell us Cupid is a good hare-finder and Vulcan a rare carpenter? Come, in what key shall a man take you, to go in the song?

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all except BENEDICK and CLAUDIO
speech.text: In mine eye she is the sweetest lady that ever I looked on.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all except BENEDICK and CLAUDIO
speech.text: I can see yet without spectacles and I see no such matter: there's her cousin, an she were not possessed with a fury, exceeds her as much in beauty as the first of May doth the last of December. But I hope you have no intent to turn husband, have you?

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all except BENEDICK and CLAUDIO
speech.text: I would scarce trust myself, though I had sworn the contrary, if Hero would be my wife.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all except BENEDICK and CLAUDIO
speech.text: Is't come to this? In faith, hath not the world one man but he will wear his cap with suspicion? Shall I never see a bachelor of three-score again? Go to, i' faith; an thou wilt needs thrust thy neck into a yoke, wear the print of it and sigh away Sundays. Look Don Pedro is returned to seek you.
What secret hath held you here, that you followed not to Leonato's?
I would your grace would constrain me to tell.
I charge thee on thy allegiance.

You hear, Count Claudio: I can be secret as a dumb man; I would have you think so; but, on my allegiance, mark you this, on my allegiance. He is in love. With who? now that is your grace's part. Mark how short his answer is;--With Hero, Leonato's short daughter.
If this were so, so were it uttered.
Like the old tale, my lord: 'it is not so, nor 'twas not so, but, indeed, God forbid it should be so.'
If my passion change not shortly, God forbid it should be otherwise.
Amen, if you love her; for the lady is very well worthy.
You speak this to fetch me in, my lord.
By my troth, I speak my thought.
And, in faith, my lord, I spoke mine.
And, by my two faiths and troths, my lord, I spoke mine.
That I love her, I feel.
That she is worthy, I know.
That I neither feel how she should be loved nor know how she should be worthy, is the opinion that fire cannot melt out of me: I will die in it at the stake.
Thou wast ever an obstinate heretic in the despite of beauty.
And never could maintain his part but in the force of his will.

That a woman conceived me, I thank her; that she brought me up, I likewise give her most humble thanks: but that I will have a recheat winded in my forehead, or hang my bugle in an invisible baldrick, all women shall pardon me. Because I will not do them the wrong to mistrust any, I will do myself the right to trust none; and the fine is, for the which I may go the finer, I will live a bachelor.
I shall see thee, ere I die, look pale with love.

With anger, with sickness, or with hunger, my lord, not with love: prove that ever I lose more blood with love than I will get again with drinking, pick out mine eyes with a ballad-maker's pen and hang me up at the door of a brothel-house for the sign of blind Cupid.
Well, if ever thou dost fall from this faith, thou wilt prove a notable argument.
If I do, hang me in a bottle like a cat and shoot at me; and he that hits me, let him be clapped on the shoulder, and called Adam.
Well, as time shall try: 'In time the savage bull doth bear the yoke.'

The savage bull may; but if ever the sensible Benedick bear it, pluck off the bull's horns and set them in my forehead: and let me be vilely painted, and in such great letters as they write 'Here is good horse to hire,' let them signify under my sign 'Here you may see Benedick the married man.'
If this should ever happen, thou wouldst be horn-mad.
Nay, if Cupid have not spent all his quiver in Venice, thou wilt quake for this shortly.
I look for an earthquake too, then.

Well, you temporize with the hours. In the meantime, good Signior Benedick, repair to Leonato's: commend me to him and tell him I will not fail him at supper; for indeed he hath made great preparation.
I have almost matter enough in me for such an embassage; and so I commit you--
To the tuition of God: From my house, if I had it,--
The sixth of July: Your loving friend, Benedick.

Nay, mock not, mock not. The body of your discourse is sometime guarded with fragments, and the guards are but slightly basted on neither: ere you flout old ends any further, examine your conscience: and so I leave you.
My liege, your highness now may do me good.
My love is thine to teach: teach it but how, And thou shalt see how apt it is to learn Any hard lesson that may do thee good.
Hath Leonato any son, my lord?
No child but Hero; she's his only heir. Dost thou affect her, Claudio?

O, my lord, When you went onward on this ended action, I look'd upon her with a soldier's eye, That liked, but had a rougher task in hand Than to drive liking to the name of love: But now I am return'd and that war-thoughts Have left their places vacant, in their rooms Come thronging soft and delicate desires, All prompting me how fair young Hero is, Saying, I liked her ere I went to wars.

Thou wilt be like a lover presently And tire the hearer with a book of words. If thou dost love fair Hero, cherish it, And I will break with her and with her father, And thou shalt have her. Was't not to this end That thou began'st to twist so fine a story?
How sweetly you do minister to love, That know love's grief by his complexion! But lest my liking might too sudden seem, I would have salved it with a longer treatise.

What need the bridge much broader than the flood? The fairest grant is the necessity. Look, what will serve is fit: 'tis once, thou lovest, And I will fit thee with the remedy. I know we shall have revelling to-night: I will assume thy part in some disguise And tell fair Hero I am Claudio, And in her bosom I'll unclasp my heart And take her hearing prisoner with the force And strong encounter of my amorous tale: Then after to her father will I break; And the conclusion is, she shall be thine. In practise let us put it presently.

scene.title: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO's house.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO's house.
speech.text: How now, brother! Where is my cousin, your son? hath he provided this music?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO's house.
speech.text: He is very busy about it. But, brother, I can tell you strange news that you yet dreamt not of.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO's house.
speech.text: Are they good?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO's house.
speech.text: As the event stamps them: but they have a good cover; they show well outward. The prince and Count Claudio, walking in a thick-pleached alley in mine orchard, were thus much overheard by a man of mine: the prince discovered to Claudio that he loved my niece your daughter and meant to acknowledge it this night in a dance: and if he found her accordant, he meant to take the present time by the top and instantly break with you of it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO's house.
speech.text: Hath the fellow any wit that told you this?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO's house.
speech.text: A good sharp fellow: I will send for him; and question him yourself.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO's house.
speech.text: No, no; we will hold it as a dream till it appear itself: but I will acquaint my daughter withal, that she may be the better prepared for an answer, if peradventure this be true. Go you and tell her of it. Cousins, you know what you have to do. O, I cry you mercy, friend; go you with me, and I will use your skill. Good cousin, have a care this busy time.
What the good-year, my lord! why are you thus out of measure sad?
There is no measure in the occasion that breeds; therefore the sadness is without limit.
You should hear reason.
And when I have heard it, what blessing brings it?
If not a present remedy, at least a patient sufferance.

I wonder that thou, being, as thou sayest thou art, born under Saturn, goest about to apply a moral medicine to a mortifying mischief. I cannot hide what I am: I must be sad when I have cause and smile at no man's jests, eat when I have stomach and wait for no man's leisure, sleep when I am drowsy and tend on no man's business, laugh when I am merry and claw no man in his humour.

Yea, but you must not make the full show of this till you may do it without controlment. You have of late stood out against your brother, and he hath ta'en you newly into his grace; where it is impossible you should take true root but by the fair weather that you make yourself: it is needful that you frame the season for your own harvest.

I had rather be a canker in a hedge than a rose in his grace, and it better fits my blood to be disdained of all than to fashion a carriage to rob love from any: in this, though I cannot be said to be a flattering honest man, it must not be denied but I am a plain-dealing villain. I am trusted with a muzzle and enfranchised with a clog; therefore I have decreed not to sing in my cage. If I had my mouth, I would bite; if I had my liberty, I would do my liking: in the meantime let me be that I am and seek not to alter me.
Can you make no use of your discontent?
I make all use of it, for I use it only. Who comes here? What news, Borachio?
I came yonder from a great supper: the prince your brother is royally entertained by Leonato: and I can give you intelligence of an intended marriage.
Will it serve for any model to build mischief on? What is he for a fool that betroths himself to unquietness?
Marry, it is your brother's right hand.
Who? the most exquisite Claudio?
Even he.
A proper squire! And who, and who? which way looks he?
Marry, on Hero, the daughter and heir of Leonato.
A very forward March-chick! How came you to this?

Being entertained for a perfumer, as I was smoking a musty room, comes me the prince and Claudio, hand in hand in sad conference: I whipt me behind the arras; and there heard it agreed upon that the prince should woo Hero for himself, and having obtained her, give her to Count Claudio.

Come, come, let us thither: this may prove food to my displeasure. That young start-up hath all the glory of my overthrow: if I can cross him any way, I bless myself every way. You are both sure, and will assist me?
To the death, my lord.
Let us to the great supper: their cheer is the greater that I am subdued. Would the cook were of my mind! Shall we go prove what's to be done?
We'll wait upon your lordship.

scene.title: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, ANTONIO, HERO, BEATRICE, and others
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Was not Count John here at supper?

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, ANTONIO, HERO, BEATRICE, and others
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: I saw him not.

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, ANTONIO, HERO, BEATRICE, and others
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: How tartly that gentleman looks! I never can see him but I am heart-burned an hour after.

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, ANTONIO, HERO, BEATRICE, and others
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: He is of a very melancholy disposition.

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, ANTONIO, HERO, BEATRICE, and others
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: He were an excellent man that were made just in the midway between him and Benedick: the one is too like an image and says nothing, and the other too like my lady's eldest son, evermore tattling.

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, ANTONIO, HERO, BEATRICE, and others
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Then half Signior Benedick's tongue in Count John's mouth, and half Count John's melancholy in Signior Benedick's face,--

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, ANTONIO, HERO, BEATRICE, and others
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: With a good leg and a good foot, uncle, and money enough in his purse, such a man would win any woman in the world, if a' could get her good-will.

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, ANTONIO, HERO, BEATRICE, and others
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: By my troth, niece, thou wilt never get thee a husband, if thou be so shrewd of thy tongue.

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, ANTONIO, HERO, BEATRICE, and others
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: In faith, she's too curst.

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, ANTONIO, HERO, BEATRICE, and others
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Too curst is more than curst: I shall lessen God's sending that way; for it is said, 'God sends a curst cow short horns;' but to a cow too curst he sends none.

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, ANTONIO, HERO, BEATRICE, and others
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: So, by being too curst, God will send you no horns.

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, ANTONIO, HERO, BEATRICE, and others
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Just, if he send me no husband; for the which blessing I am at him upon my knees every morning and evening. Lord, I could not endure a husband with a beard on his face: I had rather lie in the woollen.

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, ANTONIO, HERO, BEATRICE, and others
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: You may light on a husband that hath no beard.

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, ANTONIO, HERO, BEATRICE, and others
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: What should I do with him? dress him in my apparel and make him my waiting-gentlewoman? He that hath a beard is more than a youth, and he that hath no beard is less than a man: and he that is more than a youth is not for me, and he that is less than a man, I am not for him: therefore, I will even take sixpence in earnest of the bear-ward, and lead his apes into hell.

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, ANTONIO, HERO, BEATRICE, and others
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Well, then, go you into hell?

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, ANTONIO, HERO, BEATRICE, and others
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: No, but to the gate; and there will the devil meet me, like an old cuckold, with horns on his head, and say 'Get you to heaven, Beatrice, get you to heaven; here's no place for you maids:' so deliver I up my apes, and away to Saint Peter for the heavens; he shows me where the bachelors sit, and there live we as merry as the day is long.

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, ANTONIO, HERO, BEATRICE, and others
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Well, niece, I trust you will be ruled by your father.

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, ANTONIO, HERO, BEATRICE, and others
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Yes, faith; it is my cousin's duty to make curtsy and say 'Father, as it please you.' But yet for all that, cousin, let him be a handsome fellow, or else make another curtsy and say 'Father, as it please me.'

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, ANTONIO, HERO, BEATRICE, and others
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Well, niece, I hope to see you one day fitted with a husband.

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, ANTONIO, HERO, BEATRICE, and others
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Not till God make men of some other metal than earth. Would it not grieve a woman to be overmastered with a pierce of valiant dust? to make an account of her life to a clod of wayward marl? No, uncle, I'll none: Adam's sons are my brethren; and, truly, I hold it a sin to match in my kindred.

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, ANTONIO, HERO, BEATRICE, and others
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Daughter, remember what I told you: if the prince do solicit you in that kind, you know your answer.

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, ANTONIO, HERO, BEATRICE, and others
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: The fault will be in the music, cousin, if you be not wooed in good time: if the prince be too important, tell him there is measure in every thing and so dance out the answer. For, hear me, Hero: wooing, wedding, and repenting, is as a Scotch jig, a measure, and a cinque pace: the first suit is hot and hasty, like a Scotch jig, and full as fantastical; the wedding, mannerly-modest, as a measure, full of state and ancientry; and then comes repentance and, with his bad legs, falls into the cinque pace faster and faster, till he sink into his grave.

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, ANTONIO, HERO, BEATRICE, and others
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Cousin, you apprehend passing shrewdly.

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, ANTONIO, HERO, BEATRICE, and others
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: I have a good eye, uncle; I can see a church by daylight.

speech.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, ANTONIO, HERO, BEATRICE, and others
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: The revellers are entering, brother: make good room.

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, BALTHASAR, DON JOHN, BORACHIO, MARGARET, URSULA and others, masked
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Lady, will you walk about with your friend?

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, BALTHASAR, DON JOHN, BORACHIO, MARGARET, URSULA and others, masked
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: So you walk softly and look sweetly and say nothing, I am yours for the walk; and especially when I walk away.

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, BALTHASAR, DON JOHN, BORACHIO, MARGARET, URSULA and others, masked
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: With me in your company?

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, BALTHASAR, DON JOHN, BORACHIO, MARGARET, URSULA and others, masked
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: I may say so, when I please.

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, BALTHASAR, DON JOHN, BORACHIO, MARGARET, URSULA and others, masked
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: And when please you to say so?

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, BALTHASAR, DON JOHN, BORACHIO, MARGARET, URSULA and others, masked
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: When I like your favour; for God defend the lute should be like the case!

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, BALTHASAR, DON JOHN, BORACHIO, MARGARET, URSULA and others, masked
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: My visor is Philemon's roof; within the house is Jove.

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, BALTHASAR, DON JOHN, BORACHIO, MARGARET, URSULA and others, masked
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Why, then, your visor should be thatched.

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, BALTHASAR, DON JOHN, BORACHIO, MARGARET, URSULA and others, masked
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Speak low, if you speak love.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Well, I would you did like me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: So would not I, for your own sake; for I have many ill-qualities.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Which is one?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: I say my prayers aloud.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: I love you the better: the hearers may cry, Amen.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: God match me with a good dancer!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Amen.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: And God keep him out of my sight when the dance is done! Answer, clerk.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: No more words: the clerk is answered.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: I know you well enough; you are Signior Antonio.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: At a word, I am not.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: I know you by the waggling of your head.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: To tell you true, I counterfeit him.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: You could never do him so ill-well, unless you were the very man. Here's his dry hand up and down: you are he, you are he.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: At a word, I am not.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Come, come, do you think I do not know you by your excellent wit? can virtue hide itself? Go to, mum, you are he: graces will appear, and there's an end.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Will you not tell me who told you so?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: No, you shall pardon me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Nor will you not tell me who you are?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Not now.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: That I was disdainful, and that I had my good wit out of the 'Hundred Merry Tales:'--well this was Signior Benedick that said so.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: What's he?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: I am sure you know him well enough.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Not I, believe me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Did he never make you laugh?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: I pray you, what is he?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Why, he is the prince's jester: a very dull fool; only his gift is in devising impossible slanders: none but libertines delight in him; and the commendation is not in his wit, but in his villany; for he both pleases men and angers them, and then they laugh at him and beat him. I am sure he is in the fleet: I would he had boarded me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: When I know the gentleman, I'll tell him what you say.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Do, do: he'll but break a comparison or two on me; which, peradventure not marked or not laughed at, strikes him into melancholy; and then there's a partridge wing saved, for the fool will eat no supper that night. We must follow the leaders.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: In every good thing.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Nay, if they lead to any ill, I will leave them at the next turning.

speech.stagedir: Dance. Then exeunt all except DON JOHN, BORACHIO, and CLAUDIO
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Sure my brother is amorous on Hero and hath withdrawn her father to break with him about it. The ladies follow her and but one visor remains.

speech.stagedir: Dance. Then exeunt all except DON JOHN, BORACHIO, and CLAUDIO
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: And that is Claudio: I know him by his bearing.

speech.stagedir: Dance. Then exeunt all except DON JOHN, BORACHIO, and CLAUDIO
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Are not you Signior Benedick?

speech.stagedir: Dance. Then exeunt all except DON JOHN, BORACHIO, and CLAUDIO
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: You know me well; I am he.

speech.stagedir: Dance. Then exeunt all except DON JOHN, BORACHIO, and CLAUDIO
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Signior, you are very near my brother in his love: he is enamoured on Hero; I pray you, dissuade him from her: she is no equal for his birth: you may do the part of an honest man in it.

speech.stagedir: Dance. Then exeunt all except DON JOHN, BORACHIO, and CLAUDIO
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: How know you he loves her?

speech.stagedir: Dance. Then exeunt all except DON JOHN, BORACHIO, and CLAUDIO
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: I heard him swear his affection.

speech.stagedir: Dance. Then exeunt all except DON JOHN, BORACHIO, and CLAUDIO
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: So did I too; and he swore he would marry her to-night.

speech.stagedir: Dance. Then exeunt all except DON JOHN, BORACHIO, and CLAUDIO
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Come, let us to the banquet.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Thus answer I in the name of Benedick, But hear these ill news with the ears of Claudio. 'Tis certain so; the prince wooes for himself. Friendship is constant in all other things Save in the office and affairs of love: Therefore, all hearts in love use their own tongues; Let every eye negotiate for itself And trust no agent; for beauty is a witch Against whose charms faith melteth into blood. This is an accident of hourly proof, Which I mistrusted not. Farewell, therefore, Hero!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Count Claudio?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Yea, the same.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Come, will you go with me?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Whither?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Even to the next willow, about your own business, county. What fashion will you wear the garland of? about your neck, like an usurer's chain? or under your arm, like a lieutenant's scarf? You must wear it one way, for the prince hath got your Hero.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: I wish him joy of her.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Why, that's spoken like an honest drovier: so they sell bullocks. But did you think the prince would have served you thus?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: I pray you, leave me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Ho! now you strike like the blind man: 'twas the boy that stole your meat, and you'll beat the post.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: If it will not be, I'll leave you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Alas, poor hurt fowl! now will he creep into sedges. But that my Lady Beatrice should know me, and not know me! The prince's fool! Ha? It may be I go under that title because I am merry. Yea, but so I am apt to do myself wrong; I am not so reputed: it is the base, though bitter, disposition of Beatrice that puts the world into her person and so gives me out. Well, I'll be revenged as I may.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Now, signior, where's the count? did you see him?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Troth, my lord, I have played the part of Lady Fame. I found him here as melancholy as a lodge in a warren: I told him, and I think I told him true, that your grace had got the good will of this young lady; and I offered him my company to a willow-tree, either to make him a garland, as being forsaken, or to bind him up a rod, as being worthy to be whipped.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: To be whipped! What's his fault?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: The flat transgression of a schoolboy, who, being overjoyed with finding a birds' nest, shows it his companion, and he steals it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Wilt thou make a trust a transgression? The transgression is in the stealer.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Yet it had not been amiss the rod had been made, and the garland too; for the garland he might have worn himself, and the rod he might have bestowed on you, who, as I take it, have stolen his birds' nest.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: I will but teach them to sing, and restore them to the owner.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: If their singing answer your saying, by my faith, you say honestly.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: The Lady Beatrice hath a quarrel to you: the gentleman that danced with her told her she is much wronged by you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: O, she misused me past the endurance of a block! an oak but with one green leaf on it would have answered her; my very visor began to assume life and scold with her. She told me, not thinking I had been myself, that I was the prince's jester, that I was duller than a great thaw; huddling jest upon jest with such impossible conveyance upon me that I stood like a man at a mark, with a whole army shooting at me. She speaks poniards, and every word stabs: if her breath were as terrible as her terminations, there were no living near her; she would infect to the north star. I would not marry her, though she were endowed with all that Adam bad left him before he transgressed: she would have made Hercules have turned spit, yea, and have cleft his club to make the fire too. Come, talk not of her: you shall find her the infernal Ate in good apparel. I would to God some scholar would conjure her; for certainly, while she is here, a man may live as quiet in hell as in a sanctuary; and people sin upon purpose, because they would go thither; so, indeed, all disquiet, horror and perturbation follows her.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Look, here she comes.

speech.stagedir: Enter CLAUDIO, BEATRICE, HERO, and LEONATO
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Will your grace command me any service to the world's end? I will go on the slightest errand now to the Antipodes that you can devise to send me on; I will fetch you a tooth-picker now from the furthest inch of Asia, bring you the length of Prester John's foot, fetch you a hair off the great Cham's beard, do you any embassage to the Pigmies, rather than hold three words' conference with this harpy. You have no employment for me?

speech.stagedir: Enter CLAUDIO, BEATRICE, HERO, and LEONATO
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: None, but to desire your good company.

speech.stagedir: Enter CLAUDIO, BEATRICE, HERO, and LEONATO
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: O God, sir, here's a dish I love not: I cannot endure my Lady Tongue.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Come, lady, come; you have lost the heart of Signior Benedick.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Indeed, my lord, he lent it me awhile; and I gave him use for it, a double heart for his single one: marry, once before he won it of me with false dice, therefore your grace may well say I have lost it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: You have put him down, lady, you have put him down.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: So I would not he should do me, my lord, lest I should prove the mother of fools. I have brought Count Claudio, whom you sent me to seek.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Why, how now, count! wherefore are you sad?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Not sad, my lord.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: How then? sick?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Neither, my lord.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: The count is neither sad, nor sick, nor merry, nor well; but civil count, civil as an orange, and something of that jealous complexion.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: I' faith, lady, I think your blazon to be true; though, I'll be sworn, if he be so, his conceit is false. Here, Claudio, I have wooed in thy name, and fair Hero is won: I have broke with her father, and his good will obtained: name the day of marriage, and God give thee joy!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Count, take of me my daughter, and with her my fortunes: his grace hath made the match, and an grace say Amen to it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Speak, count, 'tis your cue.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Silence is the perfectest herald of joy: I were but little happy, if I could say how much. Lady, as you are mine, I am yours: I give away myself for you and dote upon the exchange.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Speak, cousin; or, if you cannot, stop his mouth with a kiss, and let not him speak neither.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: In faith, lady, you have a merry heart.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Yea, my lord; I thank it, poor fool, it keeps on the windy side of care. My cousin tells him in his ear that he is in her heart.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: And so she doth, cousin.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Good Lord, for alliance! Thus goes every one to the world but I, and I am sunburnt; I may sit in a corner and cry heigh-ho for a husband!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Lady Beatrice, I will get you one.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: I would rather have one of your father's getting. Hath your grace ne'er a brother like you? Your father got excellent husbands, if a maid could come by them.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Will you have me, lady?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: No, my lord, unless I might have another for working-days: your grace is too costly to wear every day. But, I beseech your grace, pardon me: I was born to speak all mirth and no matter.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Your silence most offends me, and to be merry best becomes you; for, out of question, you were born in a merry hour.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: No, sure, my lord, my mother cried; but then there was a star danced, and under that was I born. Cousins, God give you joy!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Niece, will you look to those things I told you of?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: I cry you mercy, uncle. By your grace's pardon.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: By my troth, a pleasant-spirited lady.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: There's little of the melancholy element in her, my lord: she is never sad but when she sleeps, and not ever sad then; for I have heard my daughter say, she hath often dreamed of unhappiness and waked herself with laughing.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: She cannot endure to hear tell of a husband.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: O, by no means: she mocks all her wooers out of suit.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: She were an excellent wife for Benedict.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: O Lord, my lord, if they were but a week married, they would talk themselves mad.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: County Claudio, when mean you to go to church?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: To-morrow, my lord: time goes on crutches till love have all his rites.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Not till Monday, my dear son, which is hence a just seven-night; and a time too brief, too, to have all things answer my mind.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: Come, you shake the head at so long a breathing: but, I warrant thee, Claudio, the time shall not go dully by us. I will in the interim undertake one of Hercules' labours; which is, to bring Signior Benedick and the Lady Beatrice into a mountain of affection the one with the other. I would fain have it a match, and I doubt not but to fashion it, if you three will but minister such assistance as I shall give you direction.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: My lord, I am for you, though it cost me ten nights' watchings.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: And I, my lord.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: And you too, gentle Hero?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: I will do any modest office, my lord, to help my cousin to a good husband.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speech.text: And Benedick is not the unhopefullest husband that I know. Thus far can I praise him; he is of a noble strain, of approved valour and confirmed honesty. I will teach you how to humour your cousin, that she shall fall in love with Benedick; and I, with your two helps, will so practise on Benedick that, in despite of his quick wit and his queasy stomach, he shall fall in love with Beatrice. If we can do this, Cupid is no longer an archer: his glory shall be ours, for we are the only love-gods. Go in with me, and I will tell you my drift.
It is so; the Count Claudio shall marry the daughter of Leonato.
Yea, my lord; but I can cross it.
Any bar, any cross, any impediment will be medicinable to me: I am sick in displeasure to him, and whatsoever comes athwart his affection ranges evenly with mine. How canst thou cross this marriage?
Not honestly, my lord; but so covertly that no dishonesty shall appear in me.
Show me briefly how.
I think I told your lordship a year since, how much I am in the favour of Margaret, the waiting gentlewoman to Hero.
I remember.
I can, at any unseasonable instant of the night, appoint her to look out at her lady's chamber window.
What life is in that, to be the death of this marriage?

The poison of that lies in you to temper. Go you to the prince your brother; spare not to tell him that he hath wronged his honour in marrying the renowned Claudio--whose estimation do you mightily hold up--to a contaminated stale, such a one as Hero.
What proof shall I make of that?
Proof enough to misuse the prince, to vex Claudio, to undo Hero and kill Leonato. Look you for any other issue?
Only to despite them, I will endeavour any thing.

Go, then; find me a meet hour to draw Don Pedro and the Count Claudio alone: tell them that you know that Hero loves me; intend a kind of zeal both to the prince and Claudio, as,--in love of your brother's honour, who hath made this match, and his friend's reputation, who is thus like to be cozened with the semblance of a maid,--that you have discovered thus. They will scarcely believe this without trial: offer them instances; which shall bear no less likelihood than to see me at her chamber-window, hear me call Margaret Hero, hear Margaret term me Claudio; and bring them to see this the very night before the intended wedding,--for in the meantime I will so fashion the matter that Hero shall be absent,--and there shall appear such seeming truth of Hero's disloyalty that jealousy shall be called assurance and all the preparation overthrown.
Grow this to what adverse issue it can, I will put it in practise. Be cunning in the working this, and thy fee is a thousand ducats.
Be you constant in the accusation, and my cunning shall not shame me.
I will presently go learn their day of marriage.
Boy!
Signior?
In my chamber-window lies a book: bring it hither to me in the orchard.
I am here already, sir.

I know that; but I would have thee hence, and here again. I do much wonder that one man, seeing how much another man is a fool when he dedicates his behaviors to love, will, after he hath laughed at such shallow follies in others, become the argument of his own scorn by failing in love: and such a man is Claudio. I have known when there was no music with him but the drum and the fife; and now had he rather hear the tabour and the pipe: I have known when he would have walked ten mile a-foot to see a good armour; and now will he lie ten nights awake, carving the fashion of a new doublet. He was wont to speak plain and to the purpose, like an honest man and a soldier; and now is he turned orthography; his words are a very fantastical banquet, just so many strange dishes. May I be so converted and see with these eyes? I cannot tell; I think not: I will not be sworn, but love may transform me to an oyster; but I'll take my oath on it, till he have made an oyster of me, he shall never make me such a fool. One woman is fair, yet I am well; another is wise, yet I am well; another virtuous, yet I am well; but till all graces be in one woman, one woman shall not come in my grace. Rich she shall be, that's certain; wise, or I'll none; virtuous, or I'll never cheapen her; fair, or I'll never look on her; mild, or come not near me; noble, or not I for an angel; of good discourse, an excellent musician, and her hair shall be of what colour it please God. Ha! the prince and Monsieur Love! I will hide me in the arbour.

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, and LEONATO
speech.text: Come, shall we hear this music?

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, and LEONATO
speech.text: Yea, my good lord. How still the evening is, As hush'd on purpose to grace harmony!

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, and LEONATO
speech.text: See you where Benedick hath hid himself?

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, and LEONATO
speech.text: O, very well, my lord: the music ended, We'll fit the kid-fox with a pennyworth.
Come, Balthasar, we'll hear that song again.
O, good my lord, tax not so bad a voice To slander music any more than once.
It is the witness still of excellency To put a strange face on his own perfection. I pray thee, sing, and let me woo no more.
Because you talk of wooing, I will sing; Since many a wooer doth commence his suit To her he thinks not worthy, yet he wooes, Yet will he swear he loves.
Note this before my notes; There's not a note of mine that's worth the noting.
Why, these are very crotchets that he speaks; Note, notes, forsooth, and nothing.
Now, divine air! now is his soul ravished! Is it not strange that sheeps' guts should hale souls out of men's bodies? Well, a horn for my money, when all's done.

Sigh no more, ladies, sigh no more, Men were deceivers ever, One foot in sea and one on shore, To one thing constant never: Then sigh not so, but let them go, And be you blithe and bonny, Converting all your sounds of woe Into Hey nonny, nonny. Sing no more ditties, sing no moe, Of dumps so dull and heavy; The fraud of men was ever so, Since summer first was leafy: Then sigh not so, &c.
By my troth, a good song.
And an ill singer, my lord.
Ha, no, no, faith; thou singest well enough for a shift.

An he had been a dog that should have howled thus, they would have hanged him: and I pray God his bad voice bode no mischief. I had as lief have heard the night-raven, come what plague could have come after it.
Yea, marry, dost thou hear, Balthasar? I pray thee, get us some excellent music; for to-morrow night we would have it at the Lady Hero's chamber-window.
The best I can, my lord.
Do so: farewell. Come hither, Leonato. What was it you told me of to-day, that your niece Beatrice was in love with Signior Benedick?
O, ay: stalk on. stalk on; the fowl sits. I did never think that lady would have loved any man.
No, nor I neither; but most wonderful that she should so dote on Signior Benedick, whom she hath in all outward behaviors seemed ever to abhor.
Is't possible? Sits the wind in that corner?
By my troth, my lord, I cannot tell what to think of it but that she loves him with an enraged affection: it is past the infinite of thought.
May be she doth but counterfeit.
Faith, like enough.
O God, counterfeit! There was never counterfeit of passion came so near the life of passion as she discovers it.
Why, what effects of passion shows she?
Bait the hook well; this fish will bite.
What effects, my lord? She will sit you, you heard my daughter tell you how.
She did, indeed.
How, how, pray you? You amaze me: I would have I thought her spirit had been invincible against all assaults of affection.
I would have sworn it had, my lord; especially against Benedick.
I should think this a gull, but that the white-bearded fellow speaks it: knavery cannot, sure, hide himself in such reverence.
He hath ta'en the infection: hold it up.
Hath she made her affection known to Benedick?
No; and swears she never will: that's her torment.
'Tis true, indeed; so your daughter says: 'Shall I,' says she, 'that have so oft encountered him with scorn, write to him that I love him?'
This says she now when she is beginning to write to him; for she'll be up twenty times a night, and there will she sit in her smock till she have writ a sheet of paper: my daughter tells us all.
Now you talk of a sheet of paper, I remember a pretty jest your daughter told us of.
O, when she had writ it and was reading it over, she found Benedick and Beatrice between the sheet?
That.

O, she tore the letter into a thousand halfpence; railed at herself, that she should be so immodest to write to one that she knew would flout her; 'I measure him,' says she, 'by my own spirit; for I should flout him, if he writ to me; yea, though I love him, I should.'
Then down upon her knees she falls, weeps, sobs, beats her heart, tears her hair, prays, curses; 'O sweet Benedick! God give me patience!'
She doth indeed; my daughter says so: and the ecstasy hath so much overborne her that my daughter is sometime afeared she will do a desperate outrage to herself: it is very true.
It were good that Benedick knew of it by some other, if she will not discover it.
To what end? He would make but a sport of it and torment the poor lady worse.
An he should, it were an alms to hang him. She's an excellent sweet lady; and, out of all suspicion, she is virtuous.
And she is exceeding wise.
In every thing but in loving Benedick.
O, my lord, wisdom and blood combating in so tender a body, we have ten proofs to one that blood hath the victory. I am sorry for her, as I have just cause, being her uncle and her guardian.
I would she had bestowed this dotage on me: I would have daffed all other respects and made her half myself. I pray you, tell Benedick of it, and hear what a' will say.
Were it good, think you?

Hero thinks surely she will die; for she says she will die, if he love her not, and she will die, ere she make her love known, and she will die, if he woo her, rather than she will bate one breath of her accustomed crossness.
She doth well: if she should make tender of her love, 'tis very possible he'll scorn it; for the man, as you know all, hath a contemptible spirit.
He is a very proper man.
He hath indeed a good outward happiness.
Before God! and, in my mind, very wise.
He doth indeed show some sparks that are like wit.
And I take him to be valiant.
As Hector, I assure you: and in the managing of quarrels you may say he is wise; for either he avoids them with great discretion, or undertakes them with a most Christian-like fear.
If he do fear God, a' must necessarily keep peace: if he break the peace, he ought to enter into a quarrel with fear and trembling.
And so will he do; for the man doth fear God, howsoever it seems not in him by some large jests he will make. Well I am sorry for your niece. Shall we go seek Benedick, and tell him of her love?
Never tell him, my lord: let her wear it out with good counsel.
Nay, that's impossible: she may wear her heart out first.
Well, we will hear further of it by your daughter: let it cool the while. I love Benedick well; and I could wish he would modestly examine himself, to see how much he is unworthy so good a lady.
My lord, will you walk? dinner is ready.
If he do not dote on her upon this, I will never trust my expectation.

Let there be the same net spread for her; and that must your daughter and her gentlewomen carry. The sport will be, when they hold one an opinion of another's dotage, and no such matter: that's the scene that I would see, which will be merely a dumb-show. Let us send her to call him in to dinner.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, and LEONATO
speech.text: This can be no trick: the conference was sadly borne. They have the truth of this from Hero. They seem to pity the lady: it seems her affections have their full bent. Love me! why, it must be requited. I hear how I am censured: they say I will bear myself proudly, if I perceive the love come from her; they say too that she will rather die than give any sign of affection. I did never think to marry: I must not seem proud: happy are they that hear their detractions and can put them to mending. They say the lady is fair; 'tis a truth, I can bear them witness; and virtuous; 'tis so, I cannot reprove it; and wise, but for loving me; by my troth, it is no addition to her wit, nor no great argument of her folly, for I will be horribly in love with her. I may chance have some odd quirks and remnants of wit broken on me, because I have railed so long against marriage: but doth not the appetite alter? a man loves the meat in his youth that he cannot endure in his age. Shall quips and sentences and these paper bullets of the brain awe a man from the career of his humour? No, the world must be peopled. When I said I would die a bachelor, I did not think I should live till I were married. Here comes Beatrice. By this day! she's a fair lady: I do spy some marks of love in her.
Against my will I am sent to bid you come in to dinner.
Fair Beatrice, I thank you for your pains.
I took no more pains for those thanks than you take pains to thank me: if it had been painful, I would not have come.
You take pleasure then in the message?
Yea, just so much as you may take upon a knife's point and choke a daw withal. You have no stomach, signior: fare you well.

Ha! 'Against my will I am sent to bid you come in to dinner;' there's a double meaning in that 'I took no more pains for those thanks than you took pains to thank me.' that's as much as to say, Any pains that I take for you is as easy as thanks. If I do not take pity of her, I am a villain; if I do not love her, I am a Jew. I will go get her picture.

Good Margaret, run thee to the parlor; There shalt thou find my cousin Beatrice Proposing with the prince and Claudio: Whisper her ear and tell her, I and Ursula Walk in the orchard and our whole discourse Is all of her; say that thou overheard'st us; And bid her steal into the pleached bower, Where honeysuckles, ripen'd by the sun, Forbid the sun to enter, like favourites, Made proud by princes, that advance their pride Against that power that bred it: there will she hide her, To listen our purpose. This is thy office; Bear thee well in it and leave us alone.
I'll make her come, I warrant you, presently.

Now, Ursula, when Beatrice doth come, As we do trace this alley up and down, Our talk must only be of Benedick. When I do name him, let it be thy part To praise him more than ever man did merit: My talk to thee must be how Benedick Is sick in love with Beatrice. Of this matter Is little Cupid's crafty arrow made, That only wounds by hearsay. Now begin; For look where Beatrice, like a lapwing, runs Close by the ground, to hear our conference.

The pleasant'st angling is to see the fish Cut with her golden oars the silver stream, And greedily devour the treacherous bait: So angle we for Beatrice; who even now Is couched in the woodbine coverture. Fear you not my part of the dialogue.
Then go we near her, that her ear lose nothing Of the false sweet bait that we lay for it. No, truly, Ursula, she is too disdainful; I know her spirits are as coy and wild As haggerds of the rock.
But are you sure That Benedick loves Beatrice so entirely?
So says the prince and my new-trothed lord.
And did they bid you tell her of it, madam?
They did entreat me to acquaint her of it; But I persuaded them, if they loved Benedick, To wish him wrestle with affection, And never to let Beatrice know of it.
Why did you so? Doth not the gentleman Deserve as full as fortunate a bed As ever Beatrice shall couch upon?

O god of love! I know he doth deserve As much as may be yielded to a man: But Nature never framed a woman's heart Of prouder stuff than that of Beatrice; Disdain and scorn ride sparkling in her eyes, Misprising what they look on, and her wit Values itself so highly that to her All matter else seems weak: she cannot love, Nor take no shape nor project of affection, She is so self-endeared.
Sure, sure, such carping is not commendable.

No, not to be so odd and from all fashions As Beatrice is, cannot be commendable: But who dare tell her so? If I should speak, She would mock me into air; O, she would laugh me Out of myself, press me to death with wit. Therefore let Benedick, like cover'd fire, Consume away in sighs, waste inwardly: It were a better death than die with mocks, Which is as bad as die with tickling.
Yet tell her of it: hear what she will say.

No; rather I will go to Benedick And counsel him to fight against his passion. And, truly, I'll devise some honest slanders To stain my cousin with: one doth not know How much an ill word may empoison liking.

O, do not do your cousin such a wrong. She cannot be so much without true judgment-- Having so swift and excellent a wit As she is prized to have--as to refuse So rare a gentleman as Signior Benedick.
He is the only man of Italy. Always excepted my dear Claudio.
I pray you, be not angry with me, madam, Speaking my fancy: Signior Benedick, For shape, for bearing, argument and valour, Goes foremost in report through Italy.
Indeed, he hath an excellent good name.
His excellence did earn it, ere he had it. When are you married, madam?
Why, every day, to-morrow. Come, go in: I'll show thee some attires, and have thy counsel Which is the best to furnish me to-morrow.
She's limed, I warrant you: we have caught her, madam.
If it proves so, then loving goes by haps: Some Cupid kills with arrows, some with traps.

What fire is in mine ears? Can this be true? Stand I condemn'd for pride and scorn so much? Contempt, farewell! and maiden pride, adieu! No glory lives behind the back of such. And, Benedick, love on; I will requite thee, Taming my wild heart to thy loving hand: If thou dost love, my kindness shall incite thee To bind our loves up in a holy band; For others say thou dost deserve, and I Believe it better than reportingly.

scene.title: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and LEONATO
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: I do but stay till your marriage be consummate, and then go I toward Arragon.

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and LEONATO
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: I'll bring you thither, my lord, if you'll vouchsafe me.

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and LEONATO
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: Nay, that would be as great a soil in the new gloss of your marriage as to show a child his new coat and forbid him to wear it. I will only be bold with Benedick for his company; for, from the crown of his head to the sole of his foot, he is all mirth: he hath twice or thrice cut Cupid's bow-string and the little hangman dare not shoot at him; he hath a heart as sound as a bell and his tongue is the clapper, for what his heart thinks his tongue speaks.

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and LEONATO
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: Gallants, I am not as I have been.

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and LEONATO
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: So say I methinks you are sadder.

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and LEONATO
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: I hope he be in love.

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and LEONATO
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: Hang him, truant! there's no true drop of blood in him, to be truly touched with love: if he be sad, he wants money.

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and LEONATO
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: I have the toothache.

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and LEONATO
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: Draw it.

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and LEONATO
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: Hang it!

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and LEONATO
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: You must hang it first, and draw it afterwards.

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and LEONATO
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: What! sigh for the toothache?

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and LEONATO
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: Where is but a humour or a worm.

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and LEONATO
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: Well, every one can master a grief but he that has it.

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and LEONATO
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: Yet say I, he is in love.

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and LEONATO
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: There is no appearance of fancy in him, unless it be a fancy that he hath to strange disguises; as, to be a Dutchman today, a Frenchman to-morrow, or in the shape of two countries at once, as, a German from the waist downward, all slops, and a Spaniard from the hip upward, no doublet. Unless he have a fancy to this foolery, as it appears he hath, he is no fool for fancy, as you would have it appear he is.

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and LEONATO
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: If he be not in love with some woman, there is no believing old signs: a' brushes his hat o' mornings; what should that bode?

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and LEONATO
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: Hath any man seen him at the barber's?

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and LEONATO
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: No, but the barber's man hath been seen with him, and the old ornament of his cheek hath already stuffed tennis-balls.

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and LEONATO
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: Indeed, he looks younger than he did, by the loss of a beard.

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and LEONATO
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: Nay, a' rubs himself with civet: can you smell him out by that?

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and LEONATO
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: That's as much as to say, the sweet youth's in love.

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and LEONATO
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: The greatest note of it is his melancholy.

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and LEONATO
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: And when was he wont to wash his face?

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and LEONATO
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: Yea, or to paint himself? for the which, I hear what they say of him.

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and LEONATO
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: Nay, but his jesting spirit; which is now crept into a lute-string and now governed by stops.

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and LEONATO
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: Indeed, that tells a heavy tale for him: conclude, conclude he is in love.

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and LEONATO
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: Nay, but I know who loves him.

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and LEONATO
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: That would I know too: I warrant, one that knows him not.

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and LEONATO
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: Yes, and his ill conditions; and, in despite of all, dies for him.

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and LEONATO
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: She shall be buried with her face upwards.

speech.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and LEONATO
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: Yet is this no charm for the toothache. Old signior, walk aside with me: I have studied eight or nine wise words to speak to you, which these hobby-horses must not hear.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: For my life, to break with him about Beatrice.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: 'Tis even so. Hero and Margaret have by this played their parts with Beatrice; and then the two bears will not bite one another when they meet.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: My lord and brother, God save you!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: Good den, brother.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: If your leisure served, I would speak with you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: In private?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: If it please you: yet Count Claudio may hear; for what I would speak of concerns him.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: What's the matter?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: Means your lordship to be married to-morrow?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: You know he does.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: I know not that, when he knows what I know.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: If there be any impediment, I pray you discover it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: You may think I love you not: let that appear hereafter, and aim better at me by that I now will manifest. For my brother, I think he holds you well, and in dearness of heart hath holp to effect your ensuing marriage;--surely suit ill spent and labour ill bestowed.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: Why, what's the matter?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: I came hither to tell you; and, circumstances shortened, for she has been too long a talking of, the lady is disloyal.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: Who, Hero?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: Even she; Leonato's Hero, your Hero, every man's Hero:

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: Disloyal?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: The word is too good to paint out her wickedness; I could say she were worse: think you of a worse title, and I will fit her to it. Wonder not till further warrant: go but with me to-night, you shall see her chamber-window entered, even the night before her wedding-day: if you love her then, to-morrow wed her; but it would better fit your honour to change your mind.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: May this be so?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: I will not think it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: If you dare not trust that you see, confess not that you know: if you will follow me, I will show you enough; and when you have seen more and heard more, proceed accordingly.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: If I see any thing to-night why I should not marry her to-morrow in the congregation, where I should wed, there will I shame her.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: And, as I wooed for thee to obtain her, I will join with thee to disgrace her.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: I will disparage her no farther till you are my witnesses: bear it coldly but till midnight, and let the issue show itself.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: O day untowardly turned!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: O mischief strangely thwarting!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house
speech.text: O plague right well prevented! so will you say when you have seen the sequel.

speech.stagedir: Enter DOGBERRY and VERGES with the Watch
speech.text: Are you good men and true?

speech.stagedir: Enter DOGBERRY and VERGES with the Watch
speech.text: Yea, or else it were pity but they should suffer salvation, body and soul.

speech.stagedir: Enter DOGBERRY and VERGES with the Watch
speech.text: Nay, that were a punishment too good for them, if they should have any allegiance in them, being chosen for the prince's watch.

speech.stagedir: Enter DOGBERRY and VERGES with the Watch
speech.text: Well, give them their charge, neighbour Dogberry.

speech.stagedir: Enter DOGBERRY and VERGES with the Watch
speech.text: First, who think you the most desertless man to be constable?

speech.stagedir: Enter DOGBERRY and VERGES with the Watch
speech.text: Hugh Otecake, sir, or George Seacole; for they can write and read.

speech.stagedir: Enter DOGBERRY and VERGES with the Watch
